channel.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
channel.description:
Does anyone have recommendations? I plan on buying a gaming desktop on Black Friday/Cyber Monday so pretty much anything from 999-1100 is preferred.
http://www.digitalstormonline.com/vanquish-ii.asp [b]Specs:[/b] [spoiler]- NVIDIA GTX 760 2GB - Intel Core i5 4590 CPU - 8GB 1600MHz Memory - 1TB 7200RPM HDD - ASUS H81 Chipset Motherboard - 600W Corsair CX Power Supply - DVD-R/RW/CD-R/RW - Microsoft Windows 8.1[/spoiler] My brother bought this computer ($979 version) and it seems to run well, but I have heard from other gamers that with that price the CPU could have been an i7. I want to make sure I am getting the most for my money.

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @Elrick Elrick
item.description:
@Elrick wrote:

Long story short, I ordered my video card 17 days ago and their estimated date to receive the next shipment is January 16th. Fuck that, I am not waiting that long for the video card, half of my warranties are midway to expiration and I need this bitch built like yesterday. So now the question becomes, what is the difference between the three 970 videocards? I don’t care about the price anymore, I just want the damn card.

Original: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814487075&cm_re=EVGA_GeForce_GTX970_ACX_2.0_4GB--14-487-075--Product

What I’m thinking: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814487076&cm_re=EVGA_GeForce_GTX970_ACX_2.0_4GB--14-487-076--Product

Help Obiwan Mopari, you’re my only hope.

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Fans have a certain size, and your case is going to have certain size fans that fit in it (usually multiple sizes are OK since there are multiple mounting holes), so check the specifications for your case. I would read the reviews on newegg to find fans that have a good rating, and won’t make your PC sound like an aircraft taking off (though personally I don’t mind that as long as it’s cool).

Read full topic

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:37, topic:547873”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=666777.msg4459699#msg4459699 date=1416907220]

The games I play I will be using a controller, so I’m not really worried about it. BUT, if I were to get pricier a keyboard, what would you recommend that is reasonable?

Jumping from a console controller to pc controller is a huge change. Most PC games don’t have aim assist, so while you can still use the controller, you’ll find it is much harder to stay on target until you get those twitch muscles trained. Analog sticks just don’t have the same accuracy as a mouse.

If you want to spend for a pricier keyboard, please make sure it has mechanical switches. I personally use Cherry Blues, but everyone has their own preference. Research a little bit and see what sounds appealing.
[/quote]
I do not play with aim assist on, so that isn’t too much of a worry thanks for the heads up.

Do I need any extra case fans or anything like that to keep the system cool?[/quote]
You’ll want a couple, just make sure they all push air in the same direction. In through the front, out the back for instance. You don’t wan’t all sides pulling air in, but not pushing it out anywhere.

Read full topic

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Elrick:

The games I play I will be using a controller, so I’m not really worried about it. BUT, if I were to get pricier a keyboard, what would you recommend that is reasonable?

Jumping from a console controller to pc controller is a huge change. Most PC games don’t have aim assist, so while you can still use the controller, you’ll find it is much harder to stay on target until you get those twitch muscles trained. Analog sticks just don’t have the same accuracy as a mouse.

If you want to spend for a pricier keyboard, please make sure it has mechanical switches. I personally use Cherry Blues, but everyone has their own preference. Research a little bit and see what sounds appealing.

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Elrick:

The games I play I will be using a controller, so I’m not really worried about it. BUT, if I were to get pricier a keyboard, what would you recommend that is reasonable?

http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16823109191
Something gaming grade, programmable buttons, aesthetically designed for prolonged use, but not over priced since you obviously aren’t that concerned about it that much. Also, like Ruby pointed out, mouse makes a bigger difference. (FYI, if you’re playing FPS’s such as CS:GO, you want to throw that controller out, a mouse + keyboard combo will always be more accurate than a controller.)

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

tyb97:

Better peripherals, you may think they’re overrated and overpriced, but don’t let it fool you. This is a gaming PC, no? Trust me, a gaming mouse and keyboard is going to make a HUGE difference in gaming. I don’t even want to know what DPI that mouse has lol.

Keyboard, no.

Mouse, yes. Especially for FPS like CS:GO. I’d recommend something you can set down to about 400 DPI then do the rest with the game sensitivity.

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

2. First off, you don't need that expensive ass GPU, don't listen to the mainstream, buying that high-end graphics card won't deliver as much as buying 2 of these: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814121660 Start with one, then add another down the road via SLI.

It really depends on the use-case. Do you want to play Skyrim or BF4 in 1080 on Ultra? Do you want to have a good framerate and responsiveness in online gaming? The graphics card is very important, since this is a gaming PC. I think the idea of buying one card and looking forward to later putting it in a dual-card configuration is good, but I’d start with a R9-290x or the equivalent AMD offering.

Fourthly, I've had nothing but problems with Seagate hard drives. My 320GB external hard drive USB slot broke after a year and my 500GB hard drive has serious issues with speed and it's only been a year as well. Go WD. Oh, and you might want to get a SSD or hybrid instead. You'll be glad you did.

I’ve also had problems with Seagate. I would recommend WD. They pretty much invented the HDD and have been the most reliable consumer brand in my experience as a home-user and technician. Toshiba and Hitachi are problem my next choices.

Thirdly, you're bottlenecking the processor hard with that graphics card. I have a Radeon HD 7870 and my problem in games is always the CPU. Granted, I didn't get the processor to game but rather to multi-task, so if this isn't your goal, again, go with an i7. You wouldn't be getting a 970 if your goal wasn't to game though.

http://www.tomshardware.com/forum/356983-28-8350-good-gaming

Scroll down for graphs In That Thread^
http://www.tomshardware.com/forum/356983-28-8350-good-gaming

You could probably even get the FX-6300 or 8320 and not notice a difference in most games between that or an i5 or i7. Multithreading is going to be used more and more, as well, so the AMD parts will actually improve their price to performance ratio over time.

Read full topic

item.title: Looking for the best $1000 computer
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:22, topic:547873”]1. What is a good optical drive?

  1. http://pcpartpicker.com/p/cbPrt6 Please rip this apart and tell me what I did wrong/could do better

  2. Do I need any extra fans?[/quote]I have the 8350. I recommend an i7 for anything that requires heavy processing that isn’t very multi-threaded, eg. emulation, gaming, etc.

Secondly, I don’t know about the cooling you’re getting. The stock one is okay if you don’t overclock it, but note it’s going to be LOUD. I got a cheap liquid cooler that keeps it cool and quiet, even under a full load, but then again, what you have picked out might be fine as well.

Thirdly, you’re bottlenecking the processor hard with that graphics card. I have a Radeon HD 7870 and my problem in games is always the CPU. Granted, I didn’t get the processor to game but rather to multi-task, so if this isn’t your goal, again, go with an i7. You wouldn’t be getting a 970 if your goal wasn’t to game though.

Fourthly, I’ve had nothing but problems with Seagate hard drives. My 320GB external hard drive USB slot broke after a year and my 500GB hard drive has serious issues with speed and it’s only been a year as well. Go WD. Oh, and you might want to get a SSD or hybrid instead. You’ll be glad you did.

Finally, I would suggest a wireless mouse for an extra $5.

Read full topic
